title: The Best Ways to Transfer Files Between Two Macs

steps.title: Connect your Macs with a USB or Thunderbolt cable.
steps.content: Connect your Macs with a USB or Thunderbolt cable. This method “tricks” one Mac into thinking the other is an external disk drive, making it super easy to drag and drop files between your Macs. [1] X Research source To get started, connect your Macs together with a USB, USB-C, or Thunderbolt cable. You’ll need to use a Thunderbolt cable if either of your Macs is running macOS 11 or later. Depending on what kind of ports your Macs have, you might need to use an adapter. Check this page if you need help identifying the ports on your Macs. Most modern Macs have ports that support both USB-C and Thunderbolt 3 or 4 cables. The rest of the steps for this method vary slightly depending on whether the Mac you’re using as an external disk has an older Intel processor or the newer Apple silicon (M1, M2, or M3) chip. Either way, you’ll start by connecting your Macs with a cable. To look up what kind of processor your Mac has, go to Apple menu > About This Mac .

steps.title: Reboot the external Mac in Target Disk or Share Disk Mode.
steps.content: Reboot the external Mac in Target Disk or Share Disk Mode. You’ll need to do this with the Mac that you’re using as an external disk . The right method depends on what kind of chip your Mac has. For a Mac with an Intel processor , start your Mac up while pressing the T key. Or, if you haven’t shut the Mac down yet, go to Apple menu > System Settings > General > Startup Disk > Restart in Target Disk Mode . [2] X Research source For a Mac with a silicon chip , shut down your computer, then press and hold the power button until you see a message that says Loading startup options . Then: Click Options > Continue and select a startup disk. Click Next . Enter your administrator password if prompted. Your Mac will boot into Recovery Mode. Click Utilities > Share Disk , then choose the disk or volume that you want to share (e.g., “Macintosh HD”). Click Start Sharing .

steps.title: Move your files from one Mac to the other.
steps.content: Move your files from one Mac to the other. Again, the process is a little different depending on what kind of chip the first Mac has. If the external Mac has an Intel chip , this is super simple: [3] X Research source Look for a disk icon on the desktop of the second Mac. This represents the computer that you connected in Target Disk Mode. Double-click the icon to browse your files. Drag and drop files to or from the disk to transfer them between the two Macs. If the Mac has an Apple silicon chip , there are a few more steps involved: [4] X Research source On the other Mac, open a Finder window and click Network in the left sidebar (under the Locations header). Double-click the Mac you just connected as an external disk in the Network window, then select Connect As > Guest > Connect . Drag and drop any files you want to move from one computer to the other.

steps.title: End the connection when you’re done.
steps.content: End the connection when you’re done. Once you’ve moved all the files you wanted to transfer, you can turn off the connection. For Macs with an Intel chip , simply drag the disk icon for the computer in Target Disk Mode to the Trash to eject it. Press the power button to shut the external Mac down, then disconnect the cable. [5] X Research source For Macs with an Apple silicon chip , click Stop Sharing on the Mac that’s in Share Disk Mode. Disconnect the cable. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on Wi-Fi and Bluetooth for both Macs.
steps.content: Turn on Wi-Fi and Bluetooth for both Macs. To use AirDrop, both Wi-Fi and Bluetooth must be enabled on both of your Macs: [7] X Research source Wi-Fi — If you’re not already connected to Wi-Fi, click the "Wi-Fi" icon in your Mac's menu bar and toggle on the switch next to Wi-Fi at the top of the dropdown menu. You'll also need to select and sign into a Wi-Fi network if your Mac doesn't automatically connect to one. Bluetooth — If you see the Bluetooth icon in the menu bar at the top of your screen, click it and make sure the switch is toggled on next to Bluetooth . If you don’t see the icon: Go to Apple menu > System Settings > Bluetooth and toggle the switch on next to Bluetooth .

steps.title: Make sure your Macs are on and within 30 feet (9 meters) of each other.
steps.content: Make sure your Macs are on and within 30 feet (9 meters) of each other. Since AirDrop won't work reliably past around 30 feet, you'll need to make sure that your Macs are near each other (preferably in the same room). [8] X Research source Appliances, walls, and floors can all prevent AirDrop from working within the 30-foot range. Both Macs must be turned on to complete the file transfer.

steps.title: Open Finder.
steps.content: Open Finder. Click the Finder app icon, which resembles a blue face, in your Mac's Dock.

steps.title: Turn on AirDrop if necessary.
steps.content: Turn on AirDrop if necessary. If AirDrop is disabled on either of your Macs, click the Control Center icon at the top right side of your screen. If the AirDrop icon is gray, click it and toggle AirDrop on. If it’s set to “Contacts Only,” click Everyone to ensure that you can easily transfer files between the two Macs.

steps.title: Select files to send.
steps.content: Select files to send. Go to the location of the files you want to transfer, then hold down ⌘ Command while clicking each file you want to transfer. This will allow you to select multiple files at once. You can also click and drag your cursor over the files or press Shift and click the first and last files in a range.

steps.title: Hold down Control while clicking the selected file(s).
steps.content: Hold down Control while clicking the selected file(s). Doing so will prompt a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select Share.
steps.content: Select Share . It's in the drop-down menu. Selecting it prompts a pop-out menu to appear. You can also click the Share icon at the top of the Finder window.

steps.title: Click AirDrop.
steps.content: Click AirDrop . This option is in the pop-out menu. Doing so opens the AirDrop window.

steps.title: Select your other Mac's username.
steps.content: Select your other Mac's username. Click the name of the account you use for your other Mac. This will send a file transfer request to the other Mac.

steps.title: Accept the transfer on your other Mac.
steps.content: Accept the transfer on your other Mac. When prompted, click Accept in the AirDrop notification on the other Mac. The AirDrop files should begin downloading into your Mac's Downloads folder. If both your Macs are signed into the same Apple ID, you won’t need to accept the transfer. The file(s) will be automatically shared to the second Mac. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Click Done on the first Mac.
steps.content: Click Done on the first Mac. Doing this will close the AirDrop menu.

steps.title: Plug a flash drive or external hard drive into a Mac.
steps.content: Plug a flash drive or external hard drive into a Mac. Using the drive's USB cable or connector, attach the drive to one of your Mac's USB ports. If you have a newer MacBook, you may not have a traditional rectangular USB port. If so, you'll need a USB to USB-C/Thunderbolt 3/Thunderbolt 4 adapter. If this is your first time plugging in the hard drive, you may need to format it . If so, make sure you choose Mac OS Extended (Journaled) as the format.

steps.title: Open Finder.
steps.content: Open Finder. Click the Finder app icon, which resembles a blue face, in your Mac's Dock.

steps.title: Go to the files you want to transfer.
steps.content: Go to the files you want to transfer. Open the folder where the files you want to transfer are located.

steps.title: Select the files.
steps.content: Select the files. Hold down ⌘ Command while clicking each file you want to copy. This will allow you to select several files at once. If you want to copy the entire folder's contents, click one file, then press ⌘ Command + A .

steps.title: Copy the files.
steps.content: Copy the files. Press ⌘ Command + C to do so.

steps.title: Click your external drive's name.
steps.content: Click your external drive's name. You should see it under the Locations header in the left-side menu bar in Finder. Clicking it opens your external drive. You should also be able to open the drive by double-clicking the disk icon on your desktop.

steps.title: Paste in the copied files.
steps.content: Paste in the copied files. Press ⌘ Command + V to do so. Your files will appear in the external drive's window.

steps.title: Eject and remove the drive
steps.content: Eject and remove the drive . Click the "Eject" icon to the right of the drive's name, then unplug the drive.

steps.title: Plug the drive into your other Mac.
steps.content: Plug the drive into your other Mac. This should be the Mac onto which you want to transfer your files.

steps.title: Open Finder, then click your external drive's name.
steps.content: Open Finder, then click your external drive's name. It’s in the lefthand menu bar in the Finder window, below the Locations header. You should see the files you copied onto the drive here.

steps.title: Move the files onto your Mac.
steps.content: Move the files onto your Mac. Click and drag the files from the drive onto your desktop (or into your preferred folder). This will place the files on your Mac.

steps.title: Open System Settings.
steps.content: Open System Settings . File sharing allows you to easily share files, folders, or your entire computer with others on the same network. To get started, click Apple menu > System Settings . [10] X Research source

steps.title: Go to General > Sharing.
steps.content: Go to General > Sharing . In the left-hand menu, click General , then select Sharing .

steps.title: Toggle on File Sharing.
steps.content: Toggle on File Sharing. It’s at the top of the menu. Toggle the switch to the On position (it will turn blue).

steps.title: Click the i next to File Sharing.
steps.content: Click the i next to File Sharing. This will open the file sharing settings for your Mac.

steps.title: Adjust your file sharing settings.
steps.content: Adjust your file sharing settings. To make it easy to access anything on your Mac from your other Mac, you can toggle on Allow full disk access for all users . You can also add or subtract folders to the Shared Folders menu using the + and - buttons. In the Users menu, add or subtract users you’d like to share with, and adjust their read and write privileges with the dropdown menus. You’ll need to enable Read & Write to allow these users to copy files to and from shared folders. When you’re finished making these changes, click Done . To make it as easy as possible to connect your two Macs, you may wish to allow guest users to connect. To do this, Ctrl-click the folder you want to share in the file sharing menu, select Advanced Options , and make sure Allow guest users is toggled on.

steps.title: Make sure file sharing is enabled on the other Mac.
steps.content: Make sure file sharing is enabled on the other Mac. Both Macs will need to have file sharing turned on so you can connect. [11] X Research source Go through the same steps on the second Mac. You’ll also need to make sure both Macs are connected to the same network.

steps.title: Open Finder and look for the other Mac’s name.
steps.content: Open Finder and look for the other Mac’s name. You should see it in the left sidebar under the Locations header. [12] X Research source If you don’t see the other computer, click Go > Connect to Server… in the menu bar at the top of the screen and enter the network address for the other Mac. Click Connect .

steps.title: Double-click the other Mac and select Connect As.
steps.content: Double-click the other Mac and select Connect As . Depending on how your file sharing settings are configured, you can choose Guest , Registered User , or Using an Apple ID . You may need to enter a username and password if you set that up in your file sharing settings.

steps.title: Select a shared volume or folder to access the files.
steps.content: Select a shared volume or folder to access the files. Click on the shared drive or folder you’d like to connect with. If read and write privileges are turned on for the second Mac, you should now be able to copy files to and from the shared folder to easily transfer them between computers! [13] X Research source

steps.title: Open Settings on your Mac.
steps.content: Open Settings on your Mac. This is a great option if you’re sharing between two Macs on the same Apple ID account. You can easily sync all Apple devices on the same account to share photos and files stored in your iCloud drive. To get started, go to Apple menu > System Settings… . [14] X Research source

steps.title: Click your Apple ID at the top of the menu.
steps.content: Click your Apple ID at the top of the menu. In the top left corner of the System Settings menu, you should see your Apple ID name and user icon. If you’re not logged in, do so now.

steps.title: Click iCloud Drive.
steps.content: Click iCloud Drive . You’ll see this under the Apps using iCloud header.

steps.title: Toggle on Sync this Mac.
steps.content: Toggle on Sync this Mac . It will be the first option in the pop-up window.

steps.title: Toggle on Desktop & Documents Folders.
steps.content: Toggle on Desktop & Documents Folders . This will allow you to share the files in your Desktop and Documents folders across all Apple devices that are linked to the same Apple ID. Click Done to save your settings. If you also want to share images across all your connected devices, make sure Photos is set to On under the Apps Using iCloud header.

steps.title: Access your shared files through iCloud in Finder.
steps.content: Access your shared files through iCloud in Finder. On another Mac signed into the same Apple ID, open a Finder window and click iCloud Drive in the left sidebar. If you like, you can select any file in your iCloud Drive folder and copy it to another location on your Mac.

steps.title: Use iCloud Sharing to share files with other users.
steps.content: Use iCloud Sharing to share files with other users. You can also create shared files and folders in iCloud if you want to share your files with other Mac users. To do it: [15] X Research source Go to https://www.icloud.com/ and sign in, then click Drive . Select the file or folder you want to share and click the ••• button. Click Collaborate with Others… . Choose one of the options for sharing your folder or file. You can either send an email or copy a link to send to the person you’d like to share with.

steps.title: Update both your Macs.
steps.content: Update both your Macs. This process will work best if both Macs are running the latest version of macOS. If possible, update them both before you begin. [16] X Research source Use this method to transfer all your data, including files and apps, from an old Mac to a new one.

steps.title: Make sure both Macs are connected to Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Make sure both Macs are connected to Wi-Fi. If either Mac is running El Capitan or earlier, they’ll both need to be on the same network. For later versions of macOS, it shouldn’t matter.

steps.title: Turn off any antivirus software or firewalls.
steps.content: Turn off any antivirus software or firewalls. Security software such as antivirus apps, firewalls, or VPNs may interfere with Migration Assistant. Turn these off before you continue. You can turn them on again when you’re done.

steps.title: Open Migration Assistant on your new Mac.
steps.content: Open Migration Assistant on your new Mac. Go to Finder > Applications > Utilities and open Migration Assistant. You can also find it by using the Spotlight search tool in the menu bar at the top of your screen. Double-click the app and click Continue . You may have to grant permission for the app to make changes. Enter your admin password and click OK .

steps.title: Select From a Mac, Time Machine backup, or Startup disk.
steps.content: Select From a Mac, Time Machine backup, or Startup disk . You may be prompted to select how you want to transfer your information to your new Mac. Select the top option ( From a Mac, Time Machine backup, or Startup disk ), then click Continue .

steps.title: Open Migration Assistant on your old Mac.
steps.content: Open Migration Assistant on your old Mac. You’ll need to have it open on both computers. Click Continue , then grant permission for Migration Assistant to make changes if prompted.

steps.title: Select To another Mac.
steps.content: Select To another Mac . On the next screen, specify that you will be transferring information to another Mac. Click Continue .

steps.title: Select your old Mac on the new Mac.
steps.content: Select your old Mac on the new Mac. Go back to your new Mac. You should see your old Mac in the Migration Assistant window. Select it and click Continue .

steps.title: Check for a security code on your old Mac.
steps.content: Check for a security code on your old Mac. Look back at your old Mac and see if there’s a security code on the screen. If so, double-check that it matches the code on your new Mac. Then, click Continue .

steps.title: Choose which information you want to transfer.
steps.content: Choose which information you want to transfer. Go back to the new Mac and look at the list of items you can transfer from your old Mac. For example, you may see applications, user profiles, files and folders, and your system and network settings. Check the boxes next to anything you want to transfer.

steps.title: Click Continue.
steps.content: Click Continue . At this point, the transfer will begin. It may take several hours to complete, especially if you have a slow internet connection or you’re transferring a large quantity of data. You might want to let the process run overnight.

steps.title: Understand when to use this method.
steps.content: Understand when to use this method. If you want to migrate your Mac's preferences, files, and other information onto a new Mac, you can use a Time Machine backup from your old Mac to do so. This can be a good option if you don’t have a Wi-Fi connection that is good enough to do a wireless transfer with Migration Assistant. This method shouldn't be used for regular file transfers.

steps.title: Create a Time Machine backup
steps.content: Create a Time Machine backup . If you don't already have a Time Machine backup, create one using a blank hard drive before proceeding.

steps.title: Attach the hard drive with the Time Machine backup to a Mac.
steps.content: Attach the hard drive with the Time Machine backup to a Mac. Plug your external drive into the Mac you want to set up using the Time Machine backup. If you have a newer MacBook, you may not have a traditional rectangular USB port. If so, you'll need a USB to USB-C/Thunderbolt 3/Thunderbolt 4 adapter.

steps.title: Restart your Mac.
steps.content: Restart your Mac. Click the Apple menu , click Restart... , and click Restart when prompted. Your Mac will begin to restart.

steps.title: Open Migration Assistant.
steps.content: Open Migration Assistant. You can find it in the Utilities folder in Applications , or search for it using Spotlight search . [17] X Research source Follow any onscreen prompts to set up Migration Assistant if you’re using it for the first time.

steps.title: Select From a Mac, Time Machine backup or Startup disk.
steps.content: Select From a Mac, Time Machine backup or Startup disk . Migration Assistant will ask you how you want to transfer the information to your new Mac. Select From a Mac, Time Machine backup or Startup disk , then click Continue .

steps.title: Choose your Time Machine backup.
steps.content: Choose your Time Machine backup. On the next screen, you should see the disk drive that has your backup. Select it and click Continue . You may see multiple backup files listed on the next screen. Select the most recent one—or an earlier one, if there’s a specific backup you want to use—and click Continue .

steps.title: Select the info you want to transfer.
steps.content: Select the info you want to transfer. Next, you’ll see a list of different types of data you can transfer to your new Mac, such as applications, user profiles, files and folders, and system and network settings. Check the boxes next to any of those you want to transfer, then click Continue . It might take a few hours for the process to complete.
